summary: This document is an email chain from August 2019 between legal representatives of Amazon.com and a prosecutor's office regarding a subpoena related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. Amazon's legal team raises First Amendment concerns about providing records of 'expressive materials' (e.g., books, videos) purchased by Epstein or shipped to his addresses, citing legal precedents. They discuss scheduling a call and the possibility of filing a motion to quash the subpoena.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'Mr. Epstein' in the context of a criminal investigation, with the email noting his death as a factor in evaluating First Amendment considerations for the subpoena.

persons.name: Jeffrey Goldberg
persons.context: An attorney (email signature: 'Goldberg (Legal), Jeffrey') involved in the email chain discussing the subpoena and First Amendment issues with the prosecutor's office.

events.title: Email discussion on subpoena and First Amendment issues
events.description: Email chain finalizing a call time to discuss a subpoena served on Amazon related to the Epstein investigation, with Amazon's legal team raising First Amendment concerns about producing records of 'expressive materials'.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Mentioned in the email as a factor being considered in evaluating whether First Amendment privacy interests related to the subpoena are still active.

locations: Addresses listed in the subpoena (unspecified, but related to Epstein)
keyFacts: Amazon's legal team was actively negotiating with prosecutors in August 2019 regarding a subpoena for records related to Jeffrey Epstein.

Amazon raised significant First Amendment concerns, arguing that records of 'expressive materials' (books, videos) purchased by or shipped to Epstein require a heightened legal standard to compel production.

The legal team cited multiple court cases establishing precedent that bookstores, video providers, and libraries have special protections against revealing patron choices without a compelling need, substantial nexus to the investigation, and exhaustion of other avenues.
The death of Jeffrey Epstein was noted as a potential factor that might affect the evaluation of First Amendment privacy interests related to the subpoena.
Amazon indicated it might file a motion to quash the subpoena if prosecutors continued to pursue the records of expressive materials.
